nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates of economic damages from climate change severely underestimate true damages and the dominant IAM DICE is incapable of generating economic collapse, so these estimates and models should not be used to evaluate climate risks or policy

Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs) map economic output to CO2 emissions, emissions to global temperature increase, and temperature increase to economic damages via damage functions; DICE is the influential IAM anchoring this literature

Economists' damage estimates systematically understate damages because of multiple methodological errors including neglecting tipping points, treating only weather-exposed sectors as vulnerable, and using inappropriate empirical proxies
Nordhaus's DICE damage function is quadratic D(DeltaT)=a DeltaT^2 with a calibrated small a that yields only 2.1% loss at 3 degrees C and 7.9% at 6 degrees C, leading to trivial damage estimates
Economists misrepresent or ignore climate tipping points and tipping cascades, treating them as unlikely or occurring beyond relevant time horizons

Climate science (Lenton et al. and follow-ups) identifies multiple tipping elements likely to be triggered this century and the possibility of tipping cascades that amplify warming and impacts; Nordhaus mischaracterised these findings to justify excluding tipping points from DICE

Many economic studies assume only activities directly exposed to weather (agriculture, fisheries, tourism, energy demand) are affected and treat manufacturing, services and government as insulated because they occur in controlled environments

Nordhaus 1991 and subsequent studies classified about 87% of US economic activity as 'negligibly affected' by climate change, excluding major sectors from damage calculations and using this enumeration approach to produce low aggregate damage estimates

Using spatial cross-sectional relationships between current regional temperature and income as a proxy for temporal global warming effects is invalid because it ignores historical adaptation, trade linkages, nonstationary physical climate changes, and weak statistical fit

Empirical spatial regressions (example: US state temperature vs GSP per capita) explain only a small fraction of output variance (~10%), conflate long-run adaptation and trade patterns with future climate change, and therefore produce misleading damage parameters

DICE is built on the Ramsey neoclassical growth model (representative agent maximizes discounted utility), a Cobb-Douglas production function, an atmospheric-carbon-to-temperature module, a damage function reducing output and an abatement cost function controlling emissions

Sensitivity analysis of DICE shows extreme resilience: even for much larger damage coefficients the model produces corner solutions (immediate full mitigation), deep temporary output and consumption declines, and eventual recovery; the model numerically fails only when damages exceed a very high threshold, implying DICE cannot produce endogenous economic collapse

Because of the conceptual misrepresentation of tipping points, sectoral insulation assumptions, invalid empirical proxies, and structural features of DICE that prevent collapse, economists' published damage estimates and IAMs calibrated to them (DICE, FUND, PAGE) are unreliable for risk assessment and policy design
Many IAMs and policy tools share common flawed empirical sources and calibrations, so errors propagate across models used for calculating the social cost of carbon and for policy guidance
